awd_titl_txt: SCC-RCN: Polycentric Development Toward the Vision of 21st Century Main Street in Virginia
awd_abstract_narration:
Cities and communities in the U.S. and around the world are entering a new era of transformational change, in which their inhabitants and the surrounding built and natural environments are increasingly connected by smart technologies, leading to new opportunities for innovation, improved services, and enhanced quality of life.  The Smart and Connected Communities (SCC) program supports strongly interdisciplinary, integrative research and research capacity-building activities that will improve understanding of smart and connected communities and lead to discoveries that enable sustainable change to enhance community functioning. This project is a Research Coordination Network (RCN) that focuses on achieving SCC for medium/small size, remote, and rural communities through a polycentric (multiple centers) integrated policy, design, and technology approach. The communities served by the RCN have higher barriers to information, resources, and services than larger urban communities. To reduce this gap, the PIs propose to develop need-based R&D pipelines to select solutions with the highest potential impacts to the communities. Instead of trying to connect under-connected communities to nearby large cities, this proposal aims to develop economic opportunities within the communities themselves. This topic aligns well with the vision of the SCC program, and the proposed RCN consists of a diverse group of researchers, communities, industry, government, and non-profit partners.

This award will support the development of an RCN within the Commonwealth of Virginia which will coordinate multiple partners in developing innovations utilizing smart and connected technologies. The goal of the research coordination network is to enable researchers and citizens to collaborate on research supporting enhanced quality of life for medium, small, and rural communities which frequently lack the communication and other infrastructure available in cities. The research coordination network will be led by the University of Virginia. There are 14 partner organizations including six research center partners in transportation, environment, architecture and urban planning, and engineering and technology; two State and Industry partners (Virginia Municipal League and Virginia Center for Innovative Technology); four community partners representing health services (UVA Center for Telemedicine), small and remote communities (Weldon Cooper Center), neighborhood communities (Charlottesville Neighborhood Development), and urban communities (Thriving Cities); and two national partners which support high speed networking (US-Ignite) and city-university hubs (MetroLab). Examples of research coordination include telemedicine services, transportation services, and user-centric and community-centric utilization and deployment of sensor technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Cities and communities globally are undergoing transformative changes, connecting inhabitants and environments through smart technologies. While progress has been made in large cities, smaller, remote, and rural communities face higher barriers to access information and services. Our MainStreet21 project addresses this gap by linking academic research and design to communities, establishing a research coordination network, conducting annual workshops, generating opportunities for education and training, and implementing focused seed projects that will have the highest potential positive impacts in these communities.

 

At the state level, we collected demographic, environmental, and infrastructural data to assess needs in Virginia's rural and semi-urban areas. Despite broadband expansion, access to technology alone has not solved the larger issues facing these post-industrial communities which are shrinking and struggle economically. This has had the effect of limiting investments in health care and education reducing the number of sites that serve as relevant community resource hubs. Our partnership with UVA's Telehealth program, for example, was thus used to bridge this gap remotely through expanded Telehealth services which democratize knowledge, improve access, and expand specialty care capacity in underserved communities through remote digital tools to ensure the obtaining and transfer of critical medical data and videoconferencing technology to connect specialists to primary care providers in remote regions. These efforts were complemented by projects such as HEARR, which focused on health disparities in rural regions resulting from lack of knowledge and services, isolation, underemployment, and substance abuse among others developing community-centric solutions to build a stronger local health network.

 

Notwithstanding the diminishment of institutional and infrastructural assets, Virginia has a wealth of environmental and historical cultural assets—a richness that these struggling rural communities can capitalize on. The data gleaned through our larger territorial investigation published through our webportal helped us locate specific community partners, projects, and sites for intervention developed in collaboration with community and non-profit partners in the region. Seed projects, such as We Are Martinsville (WAM), a customizable app-based urban game, Networked Public Space (NPS), an interactive environmental sensing installation in Shockoe Bottom, Richmond, and Mapping the Geospatial Image of Waynesboro, which utilizes geo-tagged data for community and urban planning, serve as prototypes for broader implementation.

 

WAM capitalizes on and amplifies a wide range of the community’s existing assets such as its history, architecture, local art, and surrounding environment to enable residents, visitors, and community stakeholders to not only understand the embedded history of the places they inhabit but also to actively contribute to their future. NPS focuses on environmental justice issues, monitoring and rendering visible the degraded environmental conditions resulting from the undesirable proximity of the sacred enslaved African burial ground to the noise and pollution of the interstate that was indiscriminately cut through a historically Black neighborhood during periods of redlining and urban renewal. Mapping Waynesboro draws from globally generated geo-tagged data through social media to expose the ways in which people interact with their environment, how they use urban amenities, and how they evaluate their experiences using analytical mapping techniques to unearth the potential of Location Based Social Networks (LBSNs) to extract critical information for community design and planning in Waynesboro, VA. A product of this work is the development of a user dashboard that can be integrated into city websites. These dashboards visualize heatmaps of social media posts, allowing the city to extract content based on keyword queries and to generate analyses of how the city is being used and perceived. 

 

Access to high-speed internet and cellular data are essential to enable more even and just development in rural and remote areas and are a baseline to attract urbanites and visitors to these areas. Digital technologies, specifically mobile and web-based tools, can provide access to remote specialized services (as in telehealth and education); while enhancing planning processes by enabling community-based interactivity and feedback. By incorporating these new techniques, we not only present a broadly applicable approach to harvesting large quantities of data about the public perception of culture and environmental assets, but also develop an evidence-based case study for combining design and digital technologies to assist small towns and cities to adapt to the ongoing transformations of their place and communities.
